Award.AwardTitle: Integrability and Geometry. Participation at XXXV Workshop on Geometric Methods in Physics and its summer school in Poland
Award.AbstractNarration:
The XXXV Workshop on Geometric Methods in Physics will take place in Bialowieza, Poland, from June 26 to July 2, 2016, and will be followed by the School on Geometry and Physics, from July 4 to July 9, 2016. The goal of this project is to increase the attendance of US-based researchers, particularly early-career faculty, postdocs, graduate students, and those without other forms of support. The series of Workshops on Geometric Methods in Physics, which has been organized by the Department of Mathematical Physics of the University of Bialystok, Poland, was created with the mission of bringing together an international community that works on a broad spectrum of problems inspired by physics; areas of special emphasis include harmonic analysis, infinite-dimensional groups, integrable systems, Lie groupoids and Lie algebroids, mathematical aspects of field theory, noncommutative geometry, operator algebras, quantization, symplectic and Poisson geometry. The series has achieved international reputation and was featured in the Newsletters of the European Mathematical society. In 2012, a summer school was added, to follow the workshop and offer nonexperts an in-depth training on selected themes of the meeting, to further promote active research and collaboration. In this 35st edition, there will be a special session on integrable systems.

The workshop is expected to promote intense activity and new collaborations in areas of theoretical mathematics that are instrumental to solve problems in physics, and reciprocally have been enriched by them, ranging from algebraic geometry to representations of infinite-dimensional Lie groups to symplectic, Poisson and noncommutative geometry. The special session will focus on the geometric, algebraic and analytic features of completely integrable systems. Plenary speakers in the special session on Integrable systems and Geometry will include E. Previato, C. Roger, L. Takhtajan, and V. Zakharov, representing very different facets of the subject. Discussion on open problems is also planned. The 2016 WGMP will be the occasion for a diverse community of experts and rising experts to come together with significant potential for advancement.

Details of speakers and participants, logistic and scientific information can be found on the conference website: http://wgmp.uwb.edu.pl

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant supported participation by USA-based junior mathematicians, graduate students, and leading mathematical scientists without travel support, in a cutting-edge, international special session on Integrable systems and Geometry at the XXXVth Workshop on Geometric Methods in Physics (WGMP),  http://wgmp.uwb.edu.pl/, in Bialowieza, Poland, June 26 - July 2, 2016, in activity throughout that meeting, and then in a follow-up summer school on Physics and Geometry in the same location, July 4 - July 9, 2016. 

The area of Integrable Systems is on the boundary with Mathematical and Theoretical Physics. Many results reported in the session have direct application in physical problems. 

Among participants supported by the grant there was significant representation of minorities as well as different kinds of institutions (research intensive, predominantly undergraduate, community college). Participants representing 12 different states were supported by the grant. 

At WGMP 2016 in total there were 72 participants coming from 15 countries. There was a well-attended discussion panel (led by Vladimir Zakharov, a pioneer of the Integrable Systems) on open problems in Integrability and Geometry. The follow up School had 34 participants and contained 7 mini-courses. 

The session is a further step in consolidating different approaches and directions within the field of Integrable Systems and its geometric aspects. It had a significant effect on the research of the participants. From responses received after the meeting: "The talks introduced me to new areas of research in mathematical physics. I also got to meet several young people who are just entering this field."; "...this meeting (the integrable systems section in particular) had an enormously large effect on my research. One of the plenary speakers, prof. V. Zakharov, stated a very important open problem for which I knew some partial answers. Two papers to this effect will appear soon. Moreover, his talk and the open problems session have greatly influences my long term research plans.''; "I think the best result of this conference is a collaboration that I started. The project began with a few computations at the conference. Later we did other particular examples... I would like to thank the organizers for planning the talk with sufficient breaks between them, which led to many discussions and one collaboration.";"...I recall the open problems session as interesting and valuable."

Following the conference, two American participants were invited to join the local organizing committee for the subsequent meetings, an invitation which they accepted for 2017 and beyond.
